title: Great Service!!!!
body: The best A&E I have ever been to! The service was efficient and I was looked after to a very high standard. I went to A and E with a displaced front tooth. I was seen within 5 mins upon arrival. The nurse who saw me looked after me very well and rang the appropriate members of the hospital and gave me paracetamol for the pain. The Maxfax department gave me a detailed description of the procedure they were going to do. They realigned my tooth and put in a splint to hold it in place. I was in and out of A and E within an hour. They also gave me advice on seeing my dentist as soon as possible and I am very grateful for their service.

readBy.name: Royal Free London NHS Foundation Trust

title: Fantastic
body: Whilst on holiday my stepdad injured his knee and we were directed here. Literally seen within minutes, after needing an X-ray and leg strapped up we were back off again in under an hour! Well done to all the staff here especially in these times. And thank you for looking after him so well.

readBy.name: Lincolnshire Community Health Services NHS Trust

title: superb care
body:
I arrived on Tuesday 11th August, in extreme pain across my stomach, I was seen immediately by reception and swiftly though to A&E and then to Lister Ward. I was diagnosed with acute pancreatitis. The warm care I received from all the staff, nurses, doctors, porters was exemplary and I can not thank them enough.
I consider myself fortunate to live near Kings College Hospital!

title: Bad experience
body: At 13 weeks pregnant I suffer recurring UTIs. I contacted the clinic and they said I need to provide a urine sample. Almost 4 weeks later, no update, no test results, no treatment. I chased it up with them twice and always told "be patient". Eventually gave up, called private doctor who explained the importance of treating UTIs immediately in pregnancy. Had a urine test which of course came back positive and was placed on appropriate antibiotics. I dread to think how Earl's Court clinic would assist if it was something serious. The receptionist was always polite (the GP on the phone not so much at all) so I have no issue with that, but if they lost my sample they need to own up to it or simply get me in for a new one,not leave me waiting for weeks on end. Not everyone can afford private GPs and if I could I would always use that option. But where does that leave people who don't have this option? Do we need to crowd and burden the emergency room?

title: Great staff Fab doctors
body: This surgery has several Administrative staff who go the extra mile and a selection of doctors who really care! These individuals make you feel like a person not a number!

title: Appalling service
body: Wanted 25hrs for a call back. Horrendous service. Really appalling service. Kept phoning and all I was told it was busy. Really upset on how I was treated to honest.

title: Urgent Care - impressive service
body: Very impressed with the seamless out of hours Urgent Care service on Saturday 29 August. We submitted the online 111 questionnaire on behalf of my 88 year old father suffering from a foot infection, were called back within 5 minutes, offered an appointment that afternoon and he was treated by a lovely friendly practitioner within 15 minutes of arriving. Thank you!

title: So easy to deal with and v helpful
body: Very positive experience, so easy to deal with especially via email, which is really convenient. I would definitely recommend this practice.

title: Professional and kind
body: I took my elderly mother for a blood test and both nurses she saw at the welcome and blood taking points were friendly, efficient and kind. They made her feel at ease and carried out their roles very professionally.

title: Small and friendly
body: Re-directed to Sevenoaks after arriving at Pembury with sprained ankle as due to covid 19 Pembury only accepting more serious cases.  Would not have gone just for sprained ankle at the current time only after two weeks it was getting worse so was a bit apprehensive about entering a hospital at current time.  Hospital was situated in very nice residential area and had a small well kept garden just outside the entrance with seating.  Inside was welcoming , friendly and efficient.  Was quickly seen by doctor who was very knowledgeable , caring and efficient and informed me I had walked too far on the foot too soon and caused torn ligaments and muscle.  I was given exercise charts and he also e-mailed me further exercises to do at home.  He personally  saw me out through back door into the garden and something I had been very apprehensive about turned out to be a good experience.

readBy.name: Kent Community Health NHS Foundation Trust

title: Brilliant practice
body: The staff was very pleasant, the counsellors were brilliant not once did I feel I was being judged, blamed or made to feel guilty, the techniques they gave me and show me were really helpful. I still have good days and bad days but the techniques help and I am so grateful for their time and their energy in helping people like myself.

title: Great staff
body: I visited the hospital a few days ago for a ct scan and I can’t fault the care I received I was running 5 minutes late but I did ring and they said come straight in to the ct Suite when I walk in the staff were ready and explained what was going to happen my appointment was all finished in 10 minutes.

title: Can't get a face to face appointment for a baby
body: We are trying to get an appointment for our 6 months old baby but it's impossible, all we get is phone calls where they are unable, in our opinion, to diagnose the problem which is various sorts of skin rash. We understand they want to try simple solutions that might help, but if after several attempts there is no improvement or any change, they clearly cannot diagnose it over the phone. We also understand they do not want to see people due to COVID, but if none of the  several treatments they prescribed over the phone worked, they could at least make an effort and see our daughter to have a proper look what she might be suffering from, instead they just keep calling and experimenting with new cream, with each new one being pretty much the same as previous one. Not very good experience with this surgery, seems like doctors are there just to be rather than help, as this is like asking a mechanic to fix your car over the phone, what is the point? Very disappointing!

title: Lovely practice
body: Just wanted to highlight the great experience I have recently had in the practice from the Receptionist to the Nurse, very helpful and made me feel at ease during the new normal we are all trying to get used to. Thank you very much!

title: So lovely
body: I went to Marie Stopes in July, during COVID-19, I couldn’t have my partner in which made it harder for be but the woman I had was amazing. From the beginning I had been offered so much support and help. This decision for me was a heartbreaking one and it is one I personally didn’t deal with easily, but because of this organisation I was able to relax my nerves and go through with it. Good luck

title: Happy with service
body:
Phone service needs over haul (with out of date message initially) but queuing system is frustrating as can be no 1 for 20 minutes!! 
Receptionist today was lovely 
Dr was helpful.. I do like the system of telephone consultations which the surgery used to do.

title: Urgent Physio service
body: Today an “Urgent Physio” visited me at home after a referral by a Rother House MC, GP yesterday. As I’d not been visited by the Community Team before, despite having a significant disability + cardiac condition, the physio asked lots of questions about me which felt quite strange - I’ve not answered so many questions about myself in a long time + to be asked how I actually felt was good too. I’ve not needed any community support until now but the GP was right in his opinion to set up the physio who’s worked out a treatment plan. The whole experience was really helpful, thanks everyone. (ED)

title: FANTASTIC PRACTICE
body:
Never had an issue getting an appointment they have always been great with myself & the kids for general appointments, checks, prescriptions and immunisation. The receptionists, GPs, Nurses & Midwives are all so lovely, caring and helpful I feel that they go out of their way for you. I really can’t recommend this surgery enough.
A special mention to Dr price who has been absolutely amazing with me, I can’t thank her enough for all the care she has given in the past 12 months.

title: Extremely helpul
body: Contacted the surgery with regards to needing some information and medical records. The staff were extremely helpful and timely with the request. I have been with this surgery since childhood and have always had amazing service and support from everyone. Thank you

title: Great staff but ???
body:
I had tongue cancer and had to have remaining bottom teeth out. An implant of 2 teeth was offered to attach a denture to and assist with my eating which is necessary ,I have  Multip!e Schlerosis and need a healthy diet. That was over 2 years ago , 2 pre op. Appointmnts 1 cancelled  surgery all 7 months ago.I am losing weight. My last appt was cancelled and told a phone appt. .in its place. No call on either phone, I  have  recorded calls and . Nos. On  phones. Only to be accused of not answering the phone call when and Only when  I had complained of such did I receive another appt. For October. That will be almost 3 years since I have been on what can only be described as a sloppy diet, everything cut through a machine. Long ago did I taste a slice of toast, a crisp or a nice biscuit. 
Or even a piece of fruit, all mpossible to eat. I am 74 years old and will be too old and frail before long with the lack of goodness. I can't remember the of time I set foot inside a Restaraunt. Eating  at get togethers was a no, so I am not too sorry to be a "vulnerable " person at the moment. I have been to the Drs and another Hospital for appts. Duly wearing a face mask and gloves. Wheelchair cleaned within an inch of Is life by my Husband. But Northwick park Nothing. To say I am upset, disppointed fed up and much more is an understatement.
I

readBy.name: London North West University Healthcare NHS Trust

title: Poor monitoring
body: I have a thyroid problem and I was supposed to be monitored. But I didn't get any letters or any other contact for months, and I went from being hyperthyroid to chronically hypothyroid to the point I lost a lot of my hair. Blood test monitoring done by nurses rather than endochrine consultants. Nurses often never there when I called. My email is anonymous as I don't want the staff to know it's me.

title: Excellent & very helpful staff
body: Absolutely excellent. Couldn't of been anymore helpful. Lyndsey from the surgery was extremely helpful and a pleasure to speak with on the phone. Made sure that I received the correct information I needed. Can't believe the outstanding and professional service she gave from the start. Felt at ease contacting them with no stress at all. A big Thanks to all the staff for doing a exceptional job, especially lyndsey who was absolutely amazing from the start. These are a true part of the NHS hero's

title: Great practice
body: Never have a complaint as they are attentive and accommodating, always manage to fit me in and very helpful and kind

title: Great service from the medical staff , BUT
body:
I had an upsetting experience when I was trying to seek advice from my GP. I was redirected to booking appointments and I don't know who answered the phone. The person did not give her name or job position. I took a while trying to describe my health problem to which the person responded : What? Then when I repeated she again said What? She was annoyed and could not find the repeating problem in my file. Eventually she did and offered a phone call back. I just thought that a person who is rude and snaps at patients , annoyed that can't understand or find information which actually was there possibly should undertake some training or chose a profession which doesn't require skills that the person obviously lacks. 
On a positive note I have received a brilliant service from the GP. I felt safe in a good environment with all aspects present to protect against COvid 19. I was listened to and everything was explained to me and I know what to expect in the future. I am really pleased and I have trust in GPs from this practise.

title: A and E and AMIA Brilliant care
body: Hi I visited A and E and Amia on Sunday 12th July, I was treated with the utmost respect and care, everyone who dealt with me was caring and polite. The nurses and doctors were fantastic

author: Larjag33
title: Horrific admission
body:
This is my second review on care opinion my first I spoke Highly about the consistently positive experiences I have had in ward 214 through this year due to infection following an operation.  
Therefore when I woke in the middle of the night feeling very unwell I knew I would get support from them and I did, they advised me to attend hospital and come via A&E due to current covid-19 procedures. This had been my experience when a similar thing happened in April, therefore, I was not to worried as care was quick and seamless, However, this time my admission via A&E can only be described as awful-degrading- absent care, lacking empathy-With questionable systems being followed in terms of medication.Due to previous sepsis I got to the hospital quickly (2am) and had been informed by staff in 214 they knew of my pending arrivalThe receptionist was abrupt in manner, almost huffy in response to my explanation that I had been advised to attend by ward staff, and there was no warmth or compassion shown whilst taking details And shown where to sit . Waited about 20 mins to be seen. I had a positive experience with the intake nurse; smiley, empathetic and quick to undertake all the necessary checks and see me through to a bayNursing bay - student nurse and a nurse, they also demonstrated positive And empathetic care albeit it with obvious pressures as I was Left for periods of time whilst they went to go and get equipment etc with no buzzer etc however they spoke me through what was to happen performed ecg and on seeing my Obs and knowing I was hard to take blood from it was then my care became “doctor led”.It was in this time, in the main A&E bays that, I experienced the worst care I have to date, truly awful and on reflection traumatising.I would describe myself as a very patient person who gives my trust to the experts, I am aware of the pressures and challenged for staff in this department and empathetic to this however that same empathy and respect was not shown to me.The doctor assigned to my care, had treated me previously which worried me as they were not empathetic at that time. After brief introduction, began attempting to take blood and whilst recognising my veins can be difficult particularly when so unwell. it is not an exaggeration to suggest this doctor must have inserted at least 20 needles into various parts of my arms/ hands including using a ultrasound machine, with no success. These attempts were frequently broken up by attending to other matters in bays around us and frequent disruptions from nursing staff coming to talk about other patients by name in front of me. Each failed attempt appears to cause the doctor to become less patient and left me feeling I was to blame and I was told on numerous occasions they could "only do as best as they can" and that they would keep going until a vein was found.I had to request several breaks as it was clear this doctor appeared to have something to prove, as it is my experience following so many unsuccessful attempts to cannulate or get blood other people would try, this was not my experience here and my request for this to happen was met with passive aggression and an implication this could only be done by them.When a canula was finally in, they commented that it was the most precarious cannula in their life but ordered fluids to be put up, by this time I Had been in a&e receiving this “treatment” for about 2 hours, thereafter at least four nurses came near my bed and I asked several times about fluids but that took at least an hour and when they started the precarious cannula wasn’t even in a vein. Again after more attempts another cannula went in and on flushing I could immediately feel it was sore however the doctor appeared not to hear this and went off.Again lots of nurses around and no communication with me having to enquire on several occasions if I was still getting fluids or antibiotics. At least an hour passed (all whilst I was very poorly) and a nurse came to administer antibiotics all whilst talking to other nurses and never checking on my general well-being. Again the cannula was not correctly in, causing pain, but allegedly did flush. The nurse went to discuss my pain with the doctor and never came back nor did I see the dr again. To my surprise shortly after this a different nurse came into my bay in abrupt manner with a tone implying I was refusing the medication, which I had been waiting for over an hour to be put up and making comments that “it was for my own good and what do I suppose they do” and despite the pain told me that the cannula was in and was informed me that it was for my own good that I try it and see how I go. I agree to this, mainly due to the fact I was exhausted felt bullied and humiliated as though I was wasting their time and the antibiotic was hooked up, I had instant pain in my arm and was advised, despite letting them know this, they would leave it for a few minutes and “see how I went”. The pain was excruciating and I had to scream out for a passing nurse who seeing my distress stopped it promptly. By this point my veins had already tissued and in agony, again an apparent inconvenience.During the above horrific experience I was asked several times by doctors and nurses what I expected them to do. I was unwell and feeling very vulnerable and the only solution I had was to admit me to ward 214 who are familiar with my care, I was concerned about the delay of treatment in A&E due to the busyness of staff, no consistent person overseeing my care, a doctor and nurse whose attitude has been very degrading and uncaring And essentially being left to continually ask about any fluids and antibiotics whilst feeling so poorly.As noted above the nurses and doctor appeared to think this was not possible until they had “ticked” all there to do list even though it was clear this was not going to be possible. The ward phoned down several times to enquire about me and luckily this appeared to bring my time in A&E to a quicker end.To finish the horrific experience the porter arrived to collect me and a further 20 min wait ensued the nurse who did attend with me yawned and moaned about their shift to the porter all the way up and on arrival on ward said they were unsure about my circumstances as had been too busy to know what had been happening, luckily this is not my first experience and I was able to answer some of the questions.Anyway, having arrived at 2am they finally appeared to relent to me going to my ward at 6.45 I feel that was almost 5 hours of wasted time for my care which I stayed in hospital for a week to recover. My experience in ward 214 was so different where I was met with consistent compassion and a cannula nurse attended promptly and inserted a cannula successfully in the first occasion and a huge contrast in care.Therefore to summarise the above, which are example of my experience- My care did not appear to follow protocol in terms of the administration of medication and cannulating- Bar two of the nursing staff, each member whom I had interactions with in A&E, briefly and inconsistently were abrupt, ineffective, dismissive and definitely not patient-centred. In particular the nurse who administered the antibiotics into my vein did so despite knowing the pain and this could have had more significant consequences if I was unable to alert staff.- the doctor leading my care showed these qualities too, and appeared to be stretched between so many patients that nothing was actioned promptly, consistently, or with any care, empathy or patients centredness. -There appeared a lot of hustle and bustle with nurses and doctors moving around but no consistency in my care, despite there being a clear plan for me to go to ward upon confirmation admission was needed which was clear in the first consultation room. On the two occasions I did enquire, this appeared to aggravate the doctor who felt this was undermining their abilities and it was quite the opposite.- there was no communication about timescales or next steps, huge delays from the decision to give fluids/ antibiotics for any attempt for these to be administered- finally and ironically, despite coming via A&E as part of the COVID screening process having spiked a sudden temperature, at no time was I asked about any other potential Covid symptoms or swabbed for this which I found quite baffling and I had to alert staff to this on ward in case it changes my care pattern.I did enquire about the name of the doctor the following day but this never came to fruition as if I had this I would also consider following a formal complaint process as I do not want myself or any other person to go through what I went through during this A&E admission when I know care and standards have been higher previously and this experience impacted on my overall well-being and emotional recovery.

readBy.name: St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students
Aberdeen City Health & Social Care Partnership
Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)

author: Keddiegirl
title: Staff assistance on discharge
body: I am aged 73. Earlier this year I had spinal surgery and was discharged after three days. As I live alone and friends were on holiday I was going home by taxi. I asked the nurse who was discharging me if someone could accompany from the ward to the hospital entrance. She said that wasn’t possible. As I made my way to the ground floor atrium I had to ask twice for directions. By the time I reached the information desk to ask where to find the taxi stance I felt extremely light-headed. Under normal circumstances I am active, clear-headed and competent but post-op I felt weak and very vulnerable. As I am soon to have another spinal operation I anxious to know how I might avail myself of assistance from the ward to the hospital exit on the day I’m discharged. Thanks.

author: Selby lad
title: Professional and caring
body:
I had a colonoscopy. The worst thing about the colonoscopy is the bowel preparation. I've gone through this a few times now, always with a morning appointment in the past. This time I had an afternoon appointment, which was much better, because the bowel preparation was divided between evening and morning. Don't believe the guidance allow 2 hours between taking the solution and your appointment, leave 4 hours. Other than that, it's not too bad. I didn't have sedation or gas and air on any of the occasions. Once in the past I had a surgeon who I felt was a bit heavy-handed, but still nothing that I couldn't cope with. This time the surgeon was very gentle and I hardly felt a thing. The nursing staff were great, as was the reception.  
I had a CT scan, with contrast. This involves the injection of a contrast dye just prior to the scan. All I felt was a hot flush and the it was over. All the staff were great.  
Next was the gastroscopy. I have written a separate report about this.  
Finally, I had a barium swallow test. This was by far the easiest of them all. Swallow some barium sulphate solution while being monitored from different angles. Nothing to it. The radiography staff were great.  
With the exception of my experience in gastroscopy, the staff at York Hospital could not have been more professional and caring. Thank you all.

readBy.name: York and Scarborough Teaching Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

author: Selby lad
title: A synopsis of my experience
body:
First, I tried to leave comments on the day of the procedure. I left a full and considered report on my experience. You can imagine my feelings when, as I submitted my report, something went wrong. I lost the report and had to start again. I decided to wait until I had calmed down. Here is a synopsis of my experience. It is intended to be taken as a guide to improving people's experience.  
I have had gastroscpies in the past, and while one would not opt for one, they have not caused pain. My experience this time was much different.  
The reception staff were pleasant, although the appointment system needs improving. I was not seen until 1 hour and 15 minutes after my allotted time for booking in, then not called through for the procedure for another hour.  
While in the waiting room, there was a man using a handkerchief as a mask, but tied in such a way that it only covered his mouth. Another patient had a mask on, but had it pulled down, again only covering his mouth. Another patient had reacted adversely to part of a procedure and was in the waiting area, no mask, coughing and sneezing.  
When I was finally called through, the procedure was to be performed via my nose, not straight down my throat. I was told that this reduces aerosol formation. I have a science background and cannot see how using the nasal route results unless aerosol production!  
The nursing staff were great. It was the doctor that I take issue with. First, the doctor wanted to spray local anaesthetic in my nose. This came in a pack and had to be assembled. part of it was dropped but they continued to assemble it, then turned round and rammed it up my nose. It was a painful experience.  
After a couple of minutes for the anaesthetic to take effect, the endoscope was brought over and the medic started to push it up my nose. The anaesthetic deadened the feeling, but did not lessen the sensation of the scope being banged repeatedly against the back of my nose. It also felt scratchy as it were down my gullet. Once in the stomac, it was much better, except for the banging against the back of my nose. The scope was passed into my duodenum and 4 samples were taken, then the scope was removed. I was much relieved. I thanked the staff and was later discharged.  
The feeling that my oesophagus had been scratched and made swallowing uncomfortable lasted for a few days. My nose was sore for several days, feeling as though I had been hit.  
If I have to have another, I will be insisting on the oral route.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)
York and Scarborough Teaching Hospital NHS Foundation Trust
Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)

title: Excellent practice, great doctors
body: I have been registered with West hampstead medical centre for over 15 years. They always provide excellent support and I had some very helpful consultations. Dr Alkizwini and Dr Bromilow are so helpful, very grateful for the support!

title: Practice is great - digital consultations not so…
body: I have found the majority of the clinicians I have met at the surgeries helpful, one female doctor was a notable exception but I find it incredibly frustrating that the group has now decided to change digital consultation providers. I had a message from Docly saying that they weren't going to be providing service in the future. There has been no communication at all from the surgery. I rang and asked when we would need to change over and just got a short-tempered man who's accent I couldn't understand - I still don't know what app I'm supposed to now be using. If we have to go through the same teething problems with the new provider as we have with Docly - it's going to be incredibly frustrating. I hope the basis of the change isn't solely based on money.

title: great practice
body: the doctor was very helpfull on the phone with giving me the information i required , and also very polite an respect when i went in

author: Phleb
title: No one answers the phone
body: My mother in law spent a week on ward 43, we spent hours on the phone but no one answers. She was supposed to be discharged yesterday and we were picking her up but no one called us to say she could go home. We couldn't get through on the phones again so she spent another night taking up a bed. We still cant get through so will have to drive 15 miles to the hospital as we did in the week as we couldn't find out what was wrong with her initially. She has spent a week alone in a single room with no tv and no one to talk to. I know the staff work very hard and its a big ward but there should be admin staff answering the phones at least.

author: nettynoo
title: Wonderful care I received
body:
I was a patient on the observation ward, albeit it was for a short time, however, I would just like to commend the staff on their caring attitude towards me while there.  
I would like to say a big thank you to all staff for taking care of me.

author: AMUpatient
title: Stay in AMU
body:
The nursing staff On Marjory Warren were all exceptional.  
Nita was particularly good - an amazing listener, comforter, helper and nurse. She made me feel at ease, safe and like I was in good hands. Her clinical skills and knowledge were also top notch and her professionalism and competence was second to none.

author: Past66
title: Surgical day care
body:
Day case for removal of tumour on the bone in my hand .  
From the point of my assessment phone call to the point of me leaving the hospital after my operation I cannot fault anything or anyone of the team that looked after me .Everything was explained to me as we went through the process and I couldn’t of felt more reassured .  
An outstanding set of people the surgeon Mr Pratt and all the staff should be very proud of what they do and they way they made me feel .  
Thank you all.

author: JoFo
title: Performing CPR for 25 minutes while waiting for ambulance
body:
I called emergency services as my 32 year old sister collapsed at home at the start of August. I advised that she was unresponsive and had a history of having a stroke.  
My sister stopped breathing and we were guided through CPR. It took 30 minutes for an ambulance to arrive, 25 of which we were performing CPR.  
When we asked if there was an emergency response vehicle we were told that the operator couldn’t tell us that.  
30 minutes for an ambulance for someone who wasn’t breathing - the nearest A&E is 25 mins away.  
My sister passed away from her injuries.  
I know everyone involved, operator, paramedics were doing the best they could in the circumstances they were in, but it’s not good enough.

author: Loverose221
title: Went above and beyond
body: I cant thank ward b2 staff enough they went above and beyond for me and made me feel at home and that I had someone to talk to they helped me through stuggles I had. I would like to name some names personally who I couldn't of got through without them being there I would like to thank Amy a hca for being there and going the extra mile for me to help me. Fern one of the nurses for always being there for me I still have my stitch picture and all the other hca nurses for just helping me get through the day I dont feel like I would of been able to start my road to recovery without them helping me every step of the way. Claire also who was my named nurse helped me through everything that she could do for me.

author: reddevilsgo1
title: Made a mess of my prescription
body: Why do the administrators make it so hard at Lomond Practice? Made a mess of my prescription and even when I checked with the pharmacy they still would not acknowledge, messed up an appt where the doctor was trying to give me a blood test as it was somebody else's notes! Was told by the doctor to make an appt and their attitude was "we don't do it that way but if the doctor said it I suppose we will have to give you an appt!" I suffer from mental health issues and each time this happens it knocks me back

author: laura2025
title: Giving birth
body:
I went to give birth to my son in this hospital and it was the worst experience of my life, I had 7 centimetres of dilation when I arrived and they did not treat me - according to them because there was no space.  
---------------------------  
Traté de dar a luz a mi hijo en este hospital y fue la peor experiencia de mi vida, tuve 7 centímetros de dilatación cuando llegué y no me trataron según ellos porque no tenía espacio.

author: Del Boy 73
title: Visit to A&E
body: I’d passed out in the early hours (330am) and fallen hitting my head and splitting my ear! I’d been sick subsequently until 930am and was referred to Treliske Hospital following a call to 111 and a conversation with a clinical Dr. I was looked after by Frankie (bloods, drip and ECG) Dr Stefan (assessment, stroke tests and CT scan) and Hannah from Max Fax who stitched my ear back together! ! All of whom were professional, friendly and very caring! Thank you all.

author: Agnes annan
title: The care and attention my husband received
body: My husband was admitted to AAU as an emergency and from entering the ward until he was transferred to ward 6 his treatment was, kind, caring professional and loving too. All the staff knew him, he was the newsagent until he retired. I myself was able to stay with him due to his condition. I have nothing but praise for every member of staff on the ward. He was transferred to ward 6 but sadly passed away. Thank you to all the staff on AAU for their kindness and their professional care of him. I shall always be eternally grateful

author: Lou1996
title: Ward 4 staff
body: I was taken to A&E a few weeks back due to taking an overdose, ran away from the hospital the next day and tried again. I was then detained under the mental health act. I was then in AMRU, then transferred to ward 4. The ward 4 staff were brilliant, one nurse in particular Natalie, was really caring and just really nice in general. I was in ward 4 for 3 nights, I struggle to sleep so I was up all night one night and the nurses didn’t mind me being up speaking to them, the night shift staff were great. The day shift staff were just as good, everyday I was hoping to get home but I had bladder retention so I was trying to fib to the nurses that I had gone to the toilet so I would get home but they explained how dangerous it would be if my bladder ruptured. They didn’t believe that I had went and joked about it. I couldn’t of asked for better nurses and the doctor that was looking after me while I was in their care. The nurses were really understanding and caring and passionate about the care they gave. Just a special shout out to Natalie and the nightshift team that had to put up with me when I couldn’t sleep, ( I can be rather annoying) but they were just amazing. Thank you! I’m wondering if I can send in a gift, like a sweet hamper or something? Just to say thank you to all of them? Please let me know, thanks!

author: don87
title: It's thanks to them I am able to write this today
body: I was admitted to the golden jubilee for a planned operation, to have my pacemaker and leads removed. Unfortunately in theatre I became very unwell and ended up in intensive care, I was been kept alive by medication as I am pacemaker dependent and I didn't have a new one in. The team in the intensive care two unit couldnt do enough for me and looked after me so well. I was then moved to ccu where again the team of drs and nurses looked after me. During my stay there I suffered a cardiac arrest and if it wasnt for the nightshift team I wouldnt be here today, they saved my life, and got me as well as they could to go back to theatre and have a pacemaker and defib fitted. The whole team in ccu went above and beyond the call of duty not just for me but for my family during what was the worst two weeks ever, they really are the best. I was transferred to Glasgow Royal Infirmary to continue my recovery. There's not enough thank yous for all the staff in the hospitals done for me its thanks to them I am able to write this today and be home with my family.

author: Agil1
title: Missed Diagnosis
body:
My son cut his finger four days later his finger began to swell and his hand was very painful. He phoned the Helensburgh Medical Centre and was given an appointment. They said they’d be very surprised if there was a foreign body in the wound, suggested he may of lay on it in bed causing the pain and gave him some cream to apply. He was told if there was no improvement by the weekend to go to the vale of Leven hospital to get an X-ray. (This would have been four days later)  
Fortunately my son wasn’t happy with this diagnosis and as the pain continued we took him to VOL hospital who promptly sent him to RAH. Turns out my son had a very bad infection in the Tendon Sheath which required him to be on a drip for days and go under general anaesthetic to have the tendon cleaned. We were told he was very lucky to have caught it early as it could have been very serious. My son said the consultant commented on it being missed at the health centre.  
We can’t fault the consultant and the hospital staff on his treatment - they were very thorough and professional. However, I do worry that due to covid we are as patients seeing people in our health centres who are perhaps not able to make these diagnosis. If there’s even a slightest bit of doubt with a patient I feel they should seek a second opinion from a doctor or make an onward referral to a hospital. We were lucky not to have taken the advice given.

author: Frightened
title: Dreadful care on stroke ward
body:
On the stroke ward. Told not to go to toilet unaided - I called and waited 2 hours! Atrocious!  
Noisy at night - staff laughing and chatting  
Cold ward with windows open. No blanket  
Not given food - breakfast or lunch.  
Needs sorting out. What sort of staff are these? There seemed to be a lot of agency staff being used.

author: Jen K
title: Patient care at Glenmore unit
body:
My 88 year old mother is very frail and has dementia. She was transferred to Glenmore unit from Monklands hospital where she remaind for approximately 8week.  
The level of care my mother received from all members of staff at the unit was exceptional.  
The staff were caring and professional, communicating frequently with the family.  
My mother's physical health improved under their care and the family are most grateful.  
I feel that it is important that the staff members are appreciated by management because they work tirelessly to provide care to their patients, and this reflects on the NHS in general.

author: Living Well
title: The staff are all wonderful
body: The staff are all wonderful, each one has a kind word and show care to each patient from start of visit to finish.   This is true from every member of the team from top to bottom.   Been in again today and the care is exceptional and first class.   The breast care is top rate and should be recognised.   I thank each member of staff.

author: Happy Feet walking
title: The importance of continuity
body:
Can I please express my thanks to the podiatrists at Antrim, Whiteabbey Hospital and Clinic.  
For the past six months they have worked tirelessly to rectify the problems with my feet.  
I single out Brenda and Sarah, they have been terrific and I've been fortunate.  
Brenda is patient, caring, knowledgable and supportive.  
Throughout she has always explained and taken me along and made me feel that I matter. To her the patient is important. Having continuous care, mainly from her, has been helpful.  
To often organisations forget the importance of the individuals they employ and the impact of interactions with clients. Being shunted backwards and forwards between care providers makes you feel like a nuisance and is counter productive. She has managed, watched and explained things.  
Your staff are brilliant.

readBy.name: Northern Health and Social Care Trust

author: 2020baby
title: Negative experience on postnatal ward
body:
I was admitted to Wheal Fortune ward following an emergency C section. I had had a 16 hour induced labour, towards the end of which I developed a high temperature due to an undiscovered infection which passed to the baby, who then needed five days of antibiotics and monitoring. By this point I was exhausted from the labour and 30 hours without sleep and still dealing with a traumatic birth, C-section and an infection, whilst also obviously being worried about my baby’s health.  
I should say to start with that most of the midwives on the ward were lovely, kind and helpful. However, unfortunately they were out-shadowed by one or two who made my time there a misery. My stay happened during the COVID-19 pandemic, which meant that my partner had to leave me once I was admitted to the ward and was only allowed to visit for three hours a day. Usually partners are able to stay and help look after the baby while the mum recovers, so not having this help made it a very difficult and lonely experience, especially being a first time mum and after a C section when it is difficult to move and lift the baby. In my opinion the staff did not compensate for this and offer the extra care and support needed.  
I was encouraged to breastfeed my baby which I did as much as I could. However over the next couple of days she was constantly crying and hungry, while I was increasingly struggling with pain and exhaustion. At night I asked several times for help with my baby as she wouldn’t settle but was just told ‘babies cry’ and to breastfeed more often (at this point I was feeding her at least every two hours, sometimes for an hour at at a time but she was still unsettled). By the second day I was unable to lift myself in or out of bed or to lift my baby out of the cot to feed her. One of the midwives could see how much pain I was in and said I should be on stronger painkillers; I was given oramorph, which was the only thing up until that point that reduced my pain. The following day the staff changed over and I asked for another dose thinking that this would not be an issue. I was told by a young and very cold-mannered midwife that I didn’t need it and should be able to manage on paracetamol and ibuprofen. I explained that the paracetamol and ibuprofen had not been sufficient to control my pain previously and that I had already been given oramorph, but again it was refused and I was left in a lot of pain.  
The next day the same midwife returned and explained that my baby needed to be weighed. Weighed the baby and went off to calculate the results whilst I fed my baby. When they returned they seemed cross and started tapping at the results, saying that my baby had lost too much weight and that this was ’not good.’ The way that I was spoken to me made me feel like I was back at school being told off by a stern teacher for doing something wrong. Then proceeded to what I can only describe as berate me, saying that I was not feeding my baby enough or correctly, that if my baby didn’t recover well from her infection it would be down to me, and that this needed to be sorted this out ‘straight away’ by getting the feeding team to come and see what I was doing wrong. My baby was at this point crying and they said, ‘See, she is hungry and you are not responding to her, this is the problem.’ (I had literally just put her down at this point following a feed). Told me that I needed to feed her ‘now’ and that I would need to spend the rest of the day feeding her constantly. At this point I was too shocked at the way I just been spoken to to respond. When they walked out I burst into tears, feeling hurt and upset but also so guilty that I had done this to my baby. I was crying so much I took myself off to the toilet to try and get it out and wash my face before the feeding team arrived.  
When I retuned to my bed a member of the feeding team was there, along with aforementioned midwife. I had prepared myself to be told off again by the new midwife and was surprised when they were immediately kind and warm and asked me what was wrong, and could see I was still fighting back tears. Then told me again and again that I didn’t need to be upset, I hadn’t done anything wrong and wasn’t sure why I blaming myself; that several midwives had mentioned how hard I had been trying with the breastfeeding and that there were lots of reasons why my baby might be underweight or my milk supply low, none of which were my fault. Also said that the weight loss was only slightly over what they would expect and that they weren't worried at all at this stage, that they were there to help and that it could easily be sorted out. At this point I was crying again and the other midwife started to look very guilty and, probably worried that I might say something, joined in saying that it was not my fault. Apologised if I had ‘misunderstood’ the earlier manner, but this did not seem like a genuine apology.Despite the midwife’s kindness and reassurance I just couldn’t forget how the first midwife had spoken to me and made me feel and I continued to cry on and off until my partner arrived, when I told him what had happened. He was really angry and wanted to go and speak to staff straight away, but I begged him not to because I didn’t want to antagonise the issue further and make my remaining time on the ward more miserable than it had been already.  
I was advised to start expressing every three hours with breastfeeds inbetween for the rest of that day and night, which I did. But my baby was still crying and hungry and at this point I asked for some formula top up which several of the midwives were very reluctant to give, and when they did gave the tiniest amounts which didn’t satisfy her. By the next morning I was exhausted having had around an hour of sleep, miserable and in pain. The staff changed over again and two lovely midwives took over my care. They both could see the state I was in and told me that if I wanted to switch to formula I could and that I didn’t need to feel guilty. I don’t think I have ever felt so relieved in my life at this point and gratefully agreed, gave my baby a decent feed of formula and had my first proper rest since I was admitted whilst my baby slept peacefully. Thankfully I was discharged that evening. I continued this way and my baby quickly got back up to a healthy weight.  
I did not attempt breastfeeding again, which I believe was in part due to how guilty and useless I was made to feel about it - I could not associate it with anything other than negative feelings and memories. Although my baby is healthy and happy, I believe that this might not have happened if the circumstances had been different. I still feel traumatised and shocked by the treatment I received and it has put me off the thought of having another baby at Treliske.  
I would however would like to thank the other midwives on Wheal Fortune Ward for being amazingly kind during an otherwise horrible stay. I should also say the midwives and anaesthetists on the Delivery Suite and in theatre were fantastic.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)
Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)

author: Asltey
title: A work colleague taking his own life
body:
Very shocking news about a previous colleague taking his life after being furloughed for 4 months.  
We phoned the service to see about getting assistance for our colleagues at work who were impacted by this.  
The organisation has helped us with information and support and regularly phoning up to check that we are ok.

author: topaz83
title: Online shopping
body:
I have Just been brought over to the amazing DRC, ( Diamond resource centre ) to do some shopping from asda/George online. Its good that we can do this online. Just wanted to say it’s good!
online shopping is new for us
From a Topaz patient.

author: Sorearm
title: Staff put me at ease
body: Went to hospital for day surgery for the removal of displaced capitellar fragments from my left elbow. Although I was nervous all the staff put me at ease and were all fantastic.

author: Reflective patient
title: Recent operation
body:
After suffering from an umbilical hernia for over a year (including one failed surgery in December last year) my situation was getting worse and I was looking about 6 months pregnant. After contacting the surgical team and speaking to Karen 10/10 she helped me get my GP refer me to the SACU unit.  
The GP initially refused to refer me or see me saying that it was the hospitals responsibility when in fact it was the GP’s. When I was eventually referred I saw two lovey doctors in the SACU department who had me sent for an urgent CT scan where it was decided I would receive my operation to repair my hernia right away.  
Initially I was admitted to Ward 4 where I was looked after by one particular nurse from whom I received first class service. And this was a consistent approach from all the lovely and friendly staff in ward 4 and the operating theatre. I thank them for that.  
I was then moved to ward 6. The service I received in ward 4 was sorely missed in ward 6. When I first arrived around 10pm I was left with no help to unpack my things and no nurses came to see me or introduce them self’s to me other than to take my OBS. During night in ward 4 all the curtains around the beds were shut except a small doorway to allow you to go to the toilet but keep your privacy. Unfortunately in ward 6 there was no such night procedure. Ward 6 could defiantly take a leaf out of ward 4’s book.

readBy.name: South Lanarkshire Health and Social Care Forum

author: Ouchy
title: Gastroscopy
body:
My experience was horrific.  
I cannot fault the nurses who were thorough and demonstrated great care.  
I elected to have my gastroscopy with an anaesthetic applied to the back of my throat, as I was told by this method that although the procedure might be uncomfortable it would not be painful.  
However, the anaesthetic was applied to my throat in a manner I consider to be haphazard and hurried. No attempt was made to discover whether the anaesthetic had taken effect or not before the tube was rapidly pushed down my throat. I was fully aware of the tube’s presence for the entire examination which was excruciatingly uncomfortable and painful. After the procedure I felt as though I had a golf ball stuck in my throat and was continually gagging due to the swollen nature of my throat. Several days later and I still have a very raw sore throat and tonsils.

author: Ellesse
title: Nutritional support and dietetics
body:
I was an inpatient at North Devon District Hospital following an adverse reaction to cancer treatment which resulted in severe diarrhea, dehydration, hypokalemia and reduced kidney function. The gastro dietician recommended a low residue diet, but the catering department were unable to offer this to me because I am Coeliac and need a gluten free diet. This meant there was very little I could eat in hospital which affected my recovery. I complained to the PALS service and I am very happy to say that my complaint has been acknowledged and changes will be made.  
However, there is no oncology dietician at North Devon Hospital and now I am considering restarting my cancer treatment there will be no one there to support me in ensuring my nutritional needs are met. I think nutrition and diet are such fundamental aspects of wellness and should be given equal importance to other aspects of care at the hospital.

readBy.name: Royal Devon University Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust

author: Ellesse
title: Fortunate to have such a good service
body: I was admitted to North Devon District Hospital for 7 days following an adverse reaction to cancer treatment. I was admitted to MAU and Capener Ward and was very unwell. All the staff, nursing, medical and auxiliary were extremely kind, caring and supportive and I very much appreciated all their help. We are very fortunate to have such a good service in North Devon.

readBy.name: Royal Devon University Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust

author: AnnieTS
title: Care and kindness
body:
I had an infection with sepsis. I was brought in by ambulance to A&E. I was assessed quickly and was then admitted to AMU. From start to finish the whole experience was made less upsetting by the care and kindness I received from everyone from the ambulance staff, in A&E and AMU. The care I received was second to none. You saved my life last week and for that I will be eternally grateful.  
Thank you to the ambulance staff, the staff in A&E, AMU and Purley 1. Thank you, Thank you, Thank you.

title: Great experience
body:
I had an inguinal hernia repair and it took 2hours from entering to leaving the surgery. The surgeon, assistant and nursing staff were professional, friendly and helpful. At the close of the surgery my comment was “so when does one get any pain??”  I hadn’t felt anything more than a slight scratch.
I loved:
- pain free surgery in a non-hospital setting
- helpful aftercare advice
- easy access to advice by    telephoning the surgery both before and after the operation
Many thanks. I wish more medical procedures could be done at local doctors’ surgeries.

author: Tiggywinkle
title: Care received in ward D7
body:
[Unhappy with 'Pain relief']  
[Very unhappy with 'Treatment']  
[Very unhappy with 'Explanations']  
[Very unhappy with 'Being listened to']  
[Unhappy with 'Future plans']  
[Very unhappy with 'Doctor']  
[Very unhappy with 'Involved in decisions']

title: Local is the only benefit
body:
Needed an appointment for my wife who suffers an illness that reoccurs 3-4 times a year.  Never able to get an appointment, even when lines are active and call at 8:15am.  Regularly told to call the following day and try then.  Staff are abrupt and need support or training in customer service.

Now the procedure has changed and we have to call the medical practice to have a doctor call us to discuss the symptoms.  Not sure if this is COVID-19 related but we do understand this.  It would be better to inform the patients of the changes to the medical centre rather than to find out when need assistance.

author: Jo37
title: Accident at home
body:
Dear Sir,  
On a Saturday in July 2020 I had a serious fall in the garden where I landed with a bump onto ornamental wall, causing incredible pain. When my husband and a friend eventually managed to get me upright it was decided that I had better go to A&E in Lincoln at the County Hospital.  
I arrived at A&E at around lunchtime. I was then sent to the Urgent Treatment Centre where I was treated by Nurse Practitioner Becky, she was helpful and kind. I was sent for a chest x-ray because of my past history and age. When I returned I was informed me that I had 2 broken ribs and a possible 3rd broken rib. (I had had previous surgery that same side where the surgeon broke ribs in order to get at problem, I had a leiomyoma as big as a large grapefruit I learned later)  
At this point I did not have my arm x-rayed. Becky said that I needed a 2 night stay in hospital to get the pain under control because of the risk of pneumonia. It was by now approximately mid afternoon.  
Becky said I needed a CT scan and would have to return to A&E for them to arrange this, so she took me there, I waited until called in and the doctor said that they couldn’t see any broken ribs on the x-ray and that after I had my arm x-rayed I could go home.  
I waited again and went to x-ray as I had been told, then waited again it was by now late afternoon, and waited and waited. A few hours later a nurse made me a cup of tea and 2 paracetamols, I never saw 1st doctor again, I was informed that he was a consultant and higher up than the ones who said I had broken ribs!  
At around 8pm a young doctor called me to a side room, they said they would look at my arm x-ray and to wait back in the waiting room, where again I sat in the only comfortable chair I could find, I never saw this doctor again either.  
At approximately 9pm I told the reception that I was tired and hungry and was going home having waited around for nearly 9 hours. I got in the car (my husband had waited in the car all this time) and we started to go home only to be called by another doctor at the hospital asking me to please come back as I had a broken arm, and 3 broken ribs, so we turned round and went back where this doctor called Habid was waiting for me. He was the best person I saw he showed me the x-rays and I clearly saw the damage for myself.  
3 broken ribs and broken elbow and a chip of bone floating around it I was put in a sling and told the fracture clinic would be contacting me to plaster my arm in the next few days. I was told to take many deep breaths to try and prevent pneumonia. The nurse asked another nurse to get a collar and cuff, I had no idea what this was, but anyway they could not find one.  
I got home at about 10pm exhausted and in a lot of pain, I had to wait to this morning to get the Oramorph.  
The only people who were compassionate to me were Becky the Nurse practitioner, the doctor Habib and the nurse with him and the younger nurse who made me tea.  
I will just add that I am an extremely vulnerable patient as I have autoimmune liver disease and have to take immune suppressants daily. I also have stomach problems.  
I think my treatment, especially by the first consultant in A&E who said I had no broken ribs, was very poor for a high-risk person or for that matter anyone.  
I had to return to A&E a day or so later, I saw triage nurse who never ever looked up when I went in, (very rude), I had temporary plaster put on the arm. I saw another nurse, who didn’t seem to believe that a collar and cuff was going to be put on, she said that they don’t put collar and cuff on an injury like this and that there were lots of them in the department at any time, I felt that I was being called a liar.

title: Failing patients/carers
body: It takes a frustratingly long time to get through to the surgery on the phone (particularly in the morning) and emails sent to the practice managers are not responded to. A home visit was missed (without notice or explanation) leading to the delay of diagnosis of a very serious condition. While there are a number of excellent, caring staff here, the surgery is in severe need of improvement starting with a complete refresh of its management.

title: wrong attitude
body:
unfortunately I have been negatively impressed with the attitude of the staff at this practice.
I have been interacting with them since the last two years and in any single occasion dealing with the staff from reception to doctors have been a positive experience. the practice got a bad attitude toward patients and several failures and missed appointments happened where the practise did not have a log or sent written confirmation overall a very low level of professionalism combined with a poor attitude and a complaint driven attitude

author: Marievc
title: Wheelchair replacement
body:
I had to have my electric wheelchair upgraded, my old one had been in fulltime service for sooo long. Being a fulltime wheelchair user brings its own daily anxiety and concerns. I was very anxious about getting a new chair. The wheelchair service engineer and team throughout the assessment and fittings were very reassuring and explained how much more suitability my new chair would bring. On the day of sign off, Rehab Engineer Jock made sure that every angle of the chair was fit to my purpose making sure all through the process I felt comfortable & safe physically but he also spent so much time going through it all, road testing in and out, that mentally I could see my anxiety turn into seeing the plus benefits.  
I am so thankful, appreciative and glad that their calm assertiveness made me see that change was required. The aftercare handover advice was very thorough ensuring my wellbeing was not compromised. 100% satisfaction with care, customer service, professionalism and kindness.

author: Ellesse
title: Complementary therapy (Reiki)
body: I was an inpatient at North Devon District Hospital. Sarah a reiki therapist, asked if I would like a treatment. From the moment she lightly touched my feet I felt waves of relaxation move up my legs and throughout my body. It was a totally relaxing experience and I would thoroughly recommend Sarah to any patients at NDDH and those using the Fern Centre.

readBy.name: Royal Devon University Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust

author: bravojt55
title: Falling over
body:
I have a nurse call me from Bromley Healthcare about my bladder and bowel issues, she is very nice and always send out the things I need in the post, they are always very good to me.  
I live alone and am 90 years old, I keep falling over when I go in the garden. I dont go out of the house but have family members who visit me. I dont know why I keep falling over backwards.  
The 1st time was a year ago and the ambulance came and took me to Princess Royal and I stayed in for a week. I was very well looked after by the staff but I had swollen legs.  
The 2nd time I had a fall in the garden the ambulance came again and wanted me to go to hospital but I took my tablets and was ok for the pain.  
I used to have injections to manage my pain in my spine but since all this infection (Covid-19) came about I haven't been having them or going to the dentist. The last one I should have had was in May but it got cancelled, I am going to ring my GP to see if I can have these again.

author: OP1
title: First experience of video consultation
body: Excellent service. On time, no travel, no parking, no waiting. Good quality sound & vision and connection with Consultant during video consultation. Content summarised by Consultant and opportunity to discuss issues and ask questions.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2022)

title: Great practice
body: Wonderful people always been there for us ,help I've had beyond words and grateful too all , especially mum and Dad who they helped . great staff friendly and polite helpful ,over all wonderfull surgery

title: Great Practice
body: The staff are really friendly, I had weekly appointments and there was minimal wait time. Nurse was very comforting and gentle with my injury, and she provided me with the best treatment to ensure my injuries healed effectively.

author: BLF2020
title: 20 hours at Morriston
body:
I was told to attend A&E at Morriston in late August 2020 after a conversation with 111 due to suspected kidney stones.  
Firstly, I’d like to point out that I’m a student nurse about to go into my third year so I understand how busy A&E is along with the rest of the hospital but I don’t see how this can mean infection control measures aren’t met and also communication was very minimal. Although I work in England, I have many friends who work within the NHS in Wales and I asked them for some advice regarding infection control. The triage process was incredibly quick but when my obs were being taken the nurse and HCA both looked at each other and hid the machine from me and didn’t state what was wrong. The HCA just asked the nurse -ecg and bloods?” and didn’t tell me why this was being done. The HCA also didn’t wear any gloves whilst taking my bloods: I have a urine sample but I only found out the results of this by reading my X-ray form when I was sent to get one done. I was then asked to sit in the minors waiting area where I sat for many hours. I did attempt to ask for pain relief which never came. My name was then called round in the main waiting area but by the time I got there they had called someone else. I knocked on the nurses station door to be told by a doctor that she couldn’t find my ‘card’ and said she’d get someone to look into it but told me to go and wait back in the main waiting area.After a couple hours a doctor called me in and he was very lovely and got me pain relief before starting the examination. He told me he was going to refer me to the surgical team and asked me to go and wait back in the waiting area. About 8am on the next day, I was called in by an agency nurse who didn’t introduce himself and just told me to follow him to a different ward which was the SDMU. I was greeted by a lovely nurse called Lorna (I think that was her name). She triaged me and then sat me in a chair to wait for a doctors to come and see me. I was waiting for around 4-5 hours before a doctor came but the urology reg, sho and f1 had a public disagreement in the middle of the waiting area which I believe should have been done in private. I would like to say a huge thank you to the F1 doctor (I’m so sorry I can’t remember your name, but you examined me alongside the urology reg) who was working on the morning of that day in SDMU as you put me at ease so much and was the only person to fully explain things through to me and when I was visibly upset, he was the only person that made an effort to comfort me. 3 people attempted to take my blood with no result, but I know that is no fault of theirs, I’m just really tricky to take blood from. I sat again for about half an hour before walking out as I decided I’d rather wait until I was back in my normal trust to seek those repeat blood tests as I didn’t feel like I was respected and listened to properly here. Many staff weren’t wearing masks or were taking them off repeatedly whilst with patients, but I don’t know fully if your infection control measures are similar to those we use with PHE, but if they are the same, I don’t think a single member of staff followed the full PPE guidance.

title: Lack of care
body: Really poor communication skills and compassion shown by male GP. Horrified by lack of care. Had enough and leaving.

title: Excellent
body:
I found the practitioner extremely experienced and supportive.  I was concerned that, because of Covid, the video sessions instead of real sessions might be less effective but that wasn't a problem as the practitioner was able to greatly assist me with my OCD and give me the tools to carry on progressing. 

I am hugely grateful for this service.

readBy.name: South London and Maudsley NHS Foundation Trust

title: First Class team
body:
I would like to thank all concerned from reception personnel in A&E to the surgeons who carried out my proceeded, in every department
all member of staff were of the highest standard, and i can not thank them enough

readBy.name: University Hospitals Birmingham NHS Foundation Trust

title: Caring professionals
body: Have been going to this practice for a number of years and have always had professional care. They can be busy but when you reach the doctor there has always been thoughtful care.

title: Let down by NHS
body:
I am very impressed by the care I receive every time I have an appointment at your hospital.  Staff and facilities are superb, and I am particularly impressed by the caring attitude shown by every Consultant whom I have visited.
However, I think your hospital is being let down by the NHS.
1.  The masks are badly designed;  the receptionist had to come out from behind her screen to tie mine on, as having had polio I can't lift my arms to do this - why can't we have masks with elastic loops?
2.  My report back from the last Consultant arrived very quickly - BUT in the form of an email attachment, not designed to be used on a Chrome book.  8 days on, Egress, the company contracted by the NHS to set up this digital service, still hasn't sorted out the problem. They are letting down yours and your staff's superb care.  As I was a private patient perhaos you could send out our reports as an easy-to-read email attachment, and not use the Egress software?

title: Great service
body: I’ve been registered with the practice for a year now and have been blown away with the consistent level of service provided. The GPs are super efficient, friendly, and helpful. Can’t recommend this surgery highly enough!

title: Friendly and professional staff
body: Everyone is so friendly especially the receptionist staff who are very supportive. I am very thankful you are in this area to care for us when we need you. Your hours are accommodating and the doctors are professional and thorough.

title: Great staff and surgeon
body: Having gone in for private surgery. I found the staff, everyone I encountered from my surgeon, to the  staff nurses, meal lady, anaesthetist, day nurses, theatre staff, night nurses, and the surgeon's secretary, and everyone else to be absolutely fantastic. I could not have gone to a better hospital. Everyone was very caring and it put me at ease. I am over the moon with the results of my operation. I now feel I have much more confidence. My surgeon managed my expectations, and I could not be happier.  I would definitely recommend woodthorp hospital to my family and friends. Thank you everyone.

title: Efficient
body:
My wife and I have used this practice for over a decade, using it regularly. Never had any major problems.

They are pro-active about health, and have a 'positive mental attitude'. They are also efficient, which is a mojor achievement in medical practices!

title: Abysmal
body:
It is close to impossible to get hold of anyone at this surgery.
On multiple occasions I have waited on hold for more than half an hour before giving up.
The 'on hold' message advises you to use the online service (every 10 seconds), but the online service does not work as this surgery is not registered with patient access. 
I am unable to re-order my repeat prescription as I need to make an an appointment.
I am unable to make an appointment as i cannot get hold of anyone.
Truly the most abysmal service I can imagine!!

title: Helpful and We'll Organised
body: The Practice excelled in End of Life treatment. Assistance was prompt and compassionate. Overall the GPs and reception team did all they could to support the whole family during this time. Pre-emptive measures taken by one GP made a massive difference to what could have been a very fraught time  particularly with the Covid-19 restrictions. The practice is more organised than it has ever been.  Despite moving goal posts the GPs and reception were organised and knowledgeable of changing services.  Without the help of one GP in particular the whole experience would have been far more difficult. I cannot praise the practice enough for their help. Prompt and supportive telephone calls made a very big difference especially given my family member's reluctance to attend hospital.

title: Not happy at all
body: gp told me to call back if medication doesn't work for my daughter but it was impossible to get appointment,even we explained the situation they just telling us call tomorrow at 8,when you trying to call,first you can't get them for 30 min, once you reach them they never have available appointment and they not letting you book for any other day,has to be same day appointment which is very hard for working people,also they can be very rude and refuse to help it seems like they want to hang up phone as soon as they can just to get rid of you and sending you to orsett hospital,if you are lucky enough to get appointment first they will give you phone call and then decide if you need to come (this was even before situation with covid-19)

title: Uncaring ward staff
body: Nurses on Chilmark ward were cold, unapproachable and made me (and the two other ladies in the ward) feel like we were an inconvenience. Attended for Laparoscopic Hysterectomy on 17th Aug and was required to stay overnight. The only nurse who showed any compassion was the night nurse. The first day shift nurse wouldn’t even look you in the eye-she looked like she was 18 and really didn’t want to be there. The next day shift Nurse- never even got her name, was cold, too busy to respond to any question - if you dared to ask anything she would cut you off and say “I’m doing something!” Every time! She gave no assistance to moving, getting out of bed, Nothing. She gave no advice or instructions for discharge either, just appeared at 7pm and said “ok you can go home now!”. Another lady who had abdominal hysterectomy was also sent home after one night!! The other lady was just completely ignored. We were just told to go and had to walk the entire length of the main hospital with no assistance and lifts out of order.  I’ve heard lots of great things about SDH but I’m afraid to say the only good thing was the surgery. The ward staff were shockingly bad,  no bedside manner or caring ability came across at all- sure they did what they needed to, but with no interaction or assistance and certainly no friendliness.  Such a shame....

title: Very caring team
body:
Few weeks ago, had a request for tests and care package for my elderly mother. Docs arranged everything then and there, and solved problems I had had with district nurses not coming out to do tests. 
Caring practice for which I am very grateful.

title: Lack of communication for asd assessment
body: Hi I am a struggling adult with mental health issues depression and anxiety I came to my gp who referred me on to the NHS services for an asd assessment in the last 12 months I've had two letters to say I am still awaiting an appointment and was still on the waiting list. In this space of time my medication has been changed 3 times I've had councelling for all of 5 weeks and with covid still not back to councelling I lost my nan in April to covid also. So it has been the worse timing. I haven't been told anything about the waiting times or if there is anywere else they can send me too for example axia as they work with the NHS and this hasn't even been considered even though there waiting times are only a couple of months I feel I've been left asd doesn't go away in adults you just feel more useless the more you are forgotten.

readBy.name: North West Boroughs Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust
St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students

title: Complete lack of response
body: Tried to get a doctors appointment - rang 52 times. Engaged for 50 of the 52 and when it eventually rang out got cut off on the other 2.

title: Very Poor
body: Telephone system is a joke. You will spend 20+ minutes in a queue before being cutoff when you are in queue position 1 or 2. It makes it almost impossible to book appointments.

title: Fantastic GP Practice
body: I have been registered to Wolverton Health Centre and I can say that I have never had a negative experience. From the reception team who are always friendly and helpful, the nurses who very knowledgeable and good at what they do, to the GP practitioners who are excellent in their patient care and who I have always found to be very supportive. I can always get an appointment when I want and the care is amazing. It is so easy for people to make a fuss in situations where something is wrong, so I just wanted to take the time to shout about the positives and how amazing they perform. Thank you.

readBy.name: Milton Keynes University Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

title: Saw what you expect from the NHS today
body:
Today I had a colonoscopy. It was on time, smooth, efficient and all the people I interacted with were knowledge, kind, caring and obviously good at their jobs.
Thank you to all involved.
As the NHS should be but even better.

title: Avoid
body: Impossible to get an appointment. Rude receptionists who are very patronising. Not a nice atmosphere and always feel unwelcome.

title: Registration of a child
body:
I recently gave birth to my son and have had to register him with the doctors. I called up to be told that I could do this online which was fine but was told this it is an adults form but can be filled out for a child. 

Some of the questions on the form have no relevance what so ever to a child and you can not go any further without completing some questions for example how much my child drinks alcohol wise. 

It would be great if you could put a child’s registration form online so that as a parent I know that I am giving you as much of the relevant and correct information about my child as possible in a user friendly way. 

Once the form was completed it stated that I needed to bring a form of ID in for my child for the registration process to be completed. Due to COVID my sons birth can not be registered most likely until next year. Due to this we have no ID apart from a hospital number. I hope that I receive some form of confirmation to say that the registration has successfully gone through. 

Apart from the above it seemed very easy to register him.

title: Ask My GP
body: Real difficulties using this facility.  Have been trying now over 2 days.  Problems with password initially. When finally logged in there was a message saying there were technical difficulties meaning they were accepting no new requests (3pm Friday) - call reception if urgent.  Tried again today and had same message at 11am.  Problem now becoming urgent and struggling to work so tried to phone on three occasions. First 2 times I was 9th in queue and unable to wait.  3rd time 6th in the queue so waited - managed to connect and was then immediately cut off.  Tried AskmyGP again - still saying technical difficulties.  Tried again to call (by now 2pm), this time I could wait and connected but promptly admonished by reception staff for not using AskmyGP. After explaining problems I was told I should try again as the earlier problems were resolved. At my insistence they took my problem details by phone and told me they would be unable to to next time as I needed to use on-line system.  Thanked them for assistance and I am now waiting for a call. Out of curiosity I tried to use Ask My GP again and it still says there are technical difficulties.  Had I followed receptions instruction I would have hit another brick wall.  This system is a real obstacle to accessing treatment for acute problems.

title: Great staff, friendly and quick.
body: Went to the Newham nhs as my little one had a fractured arm. The treatment was very quick with us being seen by the nurse, doctor and had the X-Ray done all within an hour or so. Very pleased with the level of care.

title: Receptionists need some training
body: Came in and saw the doctor, but the receptionist sat at the desk needs to learn some manners - having breakfast at the desk while talking to me, not very well dressed and awful manners. It has made me leave the surgery.

title: can't believe what they say
body:
On two occasions I have been assured which pharmacy my prescription would go to - on the second time by 3 different people - and still it was sent to the wrong place and I had to get 111 to re-issue it over the weekend.
CQC rating of "needs improvement" is too good for them.

title: Efficient service
body: This morning I had a telephone consultation with GP on my daughter's behalf (under16). Query related to a skin problem, reception staff booked me into a telephone clinic, I got a text message asking me to send query and upload photos. Dr rang back later the same morning, gave me a diagnosis, reassurance, arranged a script and signposted me to further information and advice on the internet. Excellent service, dealt with way more efficiently than the usual face to face method. Very efficient way of dealing with this type of concern. Thank you.

title: Wow
body: The practice since the new managers have taken over has been great. I phoned for a appointment and got one for the same day. A telephone call was made during the time the staff said and the nurse was so helpful. The medication was there that day too.

title: Mental Health Nurse Support
body:
I have been registered with this surgery since 2012. 
I have been receiving support for anxiety and depression from here since my first diagnosis in 2014. The service provided by the mental health nurse has been great. From helping me come to terms with what was happening, to starting treatment and now maintaining health.  
 One thing I particularly like is that it feels "normal". It doesn't feel like a mental health service- actually it's no different from seeing a GP in that regard. I've not had to wait lengthy periods to access help, appointments are not restricted, I don't feel nervous about the building or being seen/stigmatized by visiting a psych. hospital with the natural anxiety that doing so can induce. 
The nurse is very knowledgeable regards all aspects of care and has been able to refer me to talking therapies as well as provide medication support. 
I always feel that my G.P is very busy, normally a little behind in appointments and I try not to see them other than for the most serious concerns- which i think is the right approach. 
With the mental health nurse- I receive regular reviews but also feel comfortable making an appointment if I spot triggers but before my condition becomes too overwhelming to cope with.   
Seeing a mental health specialist in a GP's is also a great way to start assimilating (and de-stigmatizing)  mental and physical health. I hope it becomes more common (particularly if I ever move home!).
Overall the surgery compares well to the few others I have been registered with. GP appointments can be difficult to get but that is the same everywhere. My children visit the surgery for their appointments as well- both for immunization and general matters. I've always been able to get an appointment quickly for them, and the child care nurse covers all the normal jabs etc. Happy with that. 
The outstanding feature for me though is the mental health support provided.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)

title: Good service provided
body: Appointments always on time, never feel rushed with the GP or Practice Nurse. The telephone triage and prescription process has been made clear during the pandemic timing.

readBy.name: Sheffield Health and Social Care NHS Foundation Trust
